description: From French orgasme or New Latin orgasmus, from Ancient Greek ὀργασμός (orgasmós, “excitement, swelling”), from ὀργάω (orgáō, “to swell with moisture”).

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A spasm or sudden contraction. [17th–19th c.]
examples: Hence simple fevers are of two kinds; first, the febris irritativa, or fever with strong pulse, which consists of a previous torpor of the heart, arteries, and capillaries, and a succeeding orgasm of those vessels.

entries.meaning: A rush of sexual excitement; now specifically, the climax or peak of sexual pleasure, which occurs during sexual activity and which in males may include ejaculation and in females vaginal contractions. [from 18th c.]
A creamy white alcoholic cocktail containing amaretto, Irish cream, and coffee liqueur.

verbs.description: orgasm (third-person singular simple present orgasms, present participle orgasming, simple past and past participle orgasmed)
